abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was Modest,
            and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory. The project showed that absorptive capacity in
            the institutions being strengthened was a key constraint in
            the achievement of outcomes. While certain project
            activities were implemented expeditiously, there was a clear
            lack of ownership for the project and project activities
            were not internalized in the institutions being
            strengthened. A key ingredient for institutional performance
            and reforms is sustained and committed leadership. Long
            delays were experienced in the recruitment of staff to
            technical staff positions that were identified in the
            Staffing Plan for the restructured Ministry of Environment
            (MOE) and Central Environmental Authority (CEA). Delays in
            filling technical staff vacancies and poorly designed
            consulting inputs due to lack of absorptive capacity in MOE
            and CEA, resulted in the technical assistance consultancy
            inputs of EA1P being only marginally effective.
            Institutional development requires continuous engagement
            with the client, particularly with regard to the
            implementation of reforms. Community Environmental
            Initiatives Facility (CEIF), and Pilot Land Management
            Component (PLMC) suffered from long delays in disbursement
            of funds for community activities. Funding delays adversely
            affected project outcomes as well as a loss in community confidence.
